m1MoneySupply.description: M1 money supply grew approximately 60% in 5 years, diluting the value of every shekel you earn.

housingPrices.description: Housing prices have risen 120% in a decade, far outpacing wages.

realWages.description: Real wages have barely kept pace with inflation, meaning your purchasing power hasn't improved despite nominal salary increases.

interestRatePolicy.lowRateEffect: Low interest rates make housing speculation profitable, driving up prices for everyone. The spread between borrowing costs and rental yields encourages investors to buy properties, reducing supply for families.
interestRatePolicy.whoBenefits: Asset owners, real estate investors, and the government (inflation shrinks the real value of public debt). Who loses: workers, savers, first-time home buyers, and renters.

inflationAsHiddenTax.mechanism: When the central bank expands the money supply, each existing shekel becomes worth less. This is economically identical to a tax — but one that was never voted on, never debated in the Knesset, and affects the poorest the hardest.
inflationAsHiddenTax.annualImpactEstimate: Every 1% of unexpected inflation is equivalent to a 1% tax on all cash savings and fixed-income earnings.

currencyManipulation.foreignReservePurchases: The Bank of Israel has purchased billions in foreign currency to prevent shekel appreciation. While this helps exporters, it raises import costs for every consumer — making food, electronics, and vehicles more expensive.
currencyManipulation.effectOnConsumers: A stronger shekel would mean cheaper imports. Currency intervention effectively subsidizes exporters at the expense of every household buying imported goods.

supplyRestriction.creditChanneling: Bank regulation channels credit toward government bonds and established corporations, restricting lending to small businesses and startups that could increase competition.
supplyRestriction.bankingConcentration: 5 major banks control over 90% of Israel's banking sector, leading to higher fees and fewer choices for consumers.

whatCanBeChanged: Rules-based monetary policy (like Switzerland's debt brake) to prevent inflationary expansion
Transparency: publish real inflation rates including housing costs
Open banking regulation to increase competition and lower fees
Reduce foreign currency intervention to allow import price relief
Knesset oversight of monetary policy decisions that affect purchasing power

sources.name: Taub Center - State of the Nation Report
